children.value: Suppose we have a complicated function

children.html: f(x)f(x)f(x)

children.value: , made of natural logs and arctangents or whatever. Not friendly to deal with. We could reasonably ask the question: if there is another function

children.html: f^(x)\hat{f}(x)f^​(x)

children.value: that has the same value as

children.html: f(x)f(x)f(x)
x=x0x=x_0x=x0​

children.value: , and the same value of the first derivative (so the value of

children.html: f^(x)\hat{f}(x)f^​(x)

children.value: is changing just as rapidly as

children.html: f(x)f(x)f(x)
x=x0x=x_0x=x0​

children.value: ), and the same value of the second derivative (so the rate of change of the rate of change of

children.html: f^(x)\hat{f}(x)f^​(x)
f(x)f(x)f(x)

children.value: ), and the same value of the third derivative, and the same value of the fourth derivative, etc., onwards to the infinitieth derivative... well, that sounds like we effectively have the same functional behavior for both

children.html: f(x)f(x)f(x)
f^(x)\hat{f}(x)f^​(x)

children.value: . A function that meets this requirement can usually be constructed:

children.html: f^(x)=f(x0)+(x−x0)f′(x0)+12!(x−x0)2f′′(x0)+13!(x−x0)3f′′′(x0)…=f(x0)+∑n=1∞1n!(x−x0)nf(n)(x0)\begin{align} \hat{f}(x) &= f(x_0)+ (x-x_0)f'(x_0) + \frac{1}{2!}(x-x_0)^2f''(x_0) + \frac{1}{3!}(x-x_0)^3f'''(x_0) \dots \\ & = f(x_0) + \sum\limits_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n!}(x-x_0)^nf^{(n)}(x_0) \end{align}f^​(x)​=f(x0​)+(x−x0​)f′(x0​)+2!1​(x−x0​)2f′′(x0​)+3!1​(x−x0​)3f′′′(x0​)…=f(x0​)+n=1∑∞​n!1​(x−x0​)nf(n)(x0​)​​
f(n)f^{(n)}f(n)
nnn

children.value: th derivative. Importantly, this equivalent function,

children.html: f^(x)\hat{f}(x)f^​(x)

children.value: , is a polynomial, and polynomials are easy to deal with! The trade-off, of course, is that there are now infinity terms. We’ll see if we can tame that.
This is the Taylor Series for the function

children.html: f(x)f(x)f(x)

children.value: , and it is one of the most important ideas in engineering.

children.html: x−x0=ϵx-x_0=\epsilonx−x0​=ϵ
ϵ≪1\epsilon \ll 1ϵ≪1

children.value: . To make it concrete, let’s say

children.html: ϵ=0.1\epsilon=0.1ϵ=0.1

children.value: . What is the value, then, of

children.html: (x−x0)2=ϵ2(x-x_0)^2 = \epsilon^2(x−x0​)2=ϵ2
(x−x0)3=ϵ3(x-x_0)^3 = \epsilon^3(x−x0​)3=ϵ3

children.value: This tells us that, presuming our

children.html: xxx

children.value: is near to the reference location

children.html: x0x_0x0​

children.value: , and that the function itself is reasonably well-behaved, the successive terms in the Taylor Series become decreasingly significant. That is: we might get a decent approximation of the original function

children.html: f(x)f(x)f(x)
x0x_0x0​
f(x)≈f(x0)+(x−x0)f′(x0).f(x) \approx f(x_0) + (x-x_0)f'(x_0).f(x)≈f(x0​)+(x−x0​)f′(x0​).

children.value: This is the most practical lesson we learn from Taylor Series and will be the foundation for many of the algorithms we use in this course.
